{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16341,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Elaeagnus pungens is a fairly drought-tolerant plant once established, but regular watering is essential during its initial growth period. Water the plant deeply once a week during dry spells in the growing season to help develop a robust root system. Make sure the soil is well-drained to avoid waterlogging, as this plant does not tolerate soggy roots. Mulching around the base can help retain soil moisture and reduce the need for frequent watering. During the winter, reduce the watering frequency as the plant enters its dormant phase."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Elaeagnus pungens thrives in full sun to light shade. For optimal growth and vibrant foliage, provide it with at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. It can tolerate partial shade, but flowering and berry production may be reduced. In shady areas, ensure the plant receives some morning sun to foster growth. The plant can adapt to a variety of light conditions, but it achieves its best foliage color and flowering when grown in sunnier spots. If grown indoors or in a shaded spot, consider supplementing with artificial grow lights to provide adequate light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Elaeagnus pungens is important for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. It is best done in late winter to early spring before new growth begins. Start by removing any dead or damaged branches to improve the plant's health and appearance. Then, thin out overcrowded areas to allow sunlight and air to penetrate through the plant. Be cautious not to over-prune, as this can reduce flowering. Lightly trim back longer branches to maintain the desired shape. Regular pruning will help manage the plant's size and keep it neat and healthy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"thorny olive","description":"Elaeagnus pungens is a species of flowering plant in the family Elaeagnaceae, known by the common names thorny olive, spiny oleaster and silverthorn; also by the family name \"oleaster\". It is native to Asia, including China and Japan. It is present in the southeastern United States as an introduced species, a common landscaping and ornamental plant, and sometimes an invasive species.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["China","Japan"],"other_name":["thorny olive"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew","Anthracnose"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Elaeagnus pungens"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Adjust the watering schedule based on seasonal changes, providing more water during dry spells and less during periods of heavy rain."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex nigra thrives in conditions ranging from full sun to partial shade. It is adaptable and can tolerate a variety of light conditions, but providing a balance of sun and shade, especially in areas with intense summer heat, will result in the healthiest growth and most vibrant color in its foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex nigra is relatively straightforward and promotes healthy growth. In early spring, cut back any dead or damaged foliage to allow fresh new growth. Throughout the growing season, you may also remove any spent or unsightly leaves to maintain a tidy appearance. For larger, overgrown clumps, dividing the plant every few years not only rejuvenates the plant but also helps encourage new shoots. Division is best done in early spring or autumn. Avoid heavy pruning in late fall as the foliage helps protect the root system during the winter months."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"smooth black sedge","description":"Carex nigra (L.) Regular maintenance pruning will ensure the plant retains its natural elegance and blooms beautifully each season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bigleaf Snowbell","description":"Styrax grandifolius, the bigleaf snowbell or bigleaf storax, is a plant species native to the southeastern United States, ranging from Virginia south to Florida and west to Texas and Missouri. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16840,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Plantago rugelii prefers moderate watering. It's important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged, as excessive water can damage the roots. When watering, aim to thoroughly moisten the soil and then allow the top inch to dry out before watering again. During hot and dry weather, you might need to water more frequently, possibly even daily if the plant is in full sun. Ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent standing water, which can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Plantago rugelii thrives in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. Morning sunlight can be particularly beneficial, reducing the intensity of afternoon heat. In regions with particularly hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the plant from wilting or scorching. If grown in too much shade, Plantago rugelii might become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Strike a balance that suits your regional climate to ensure healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Plantago rugelii is generally not necessary for the health of the plant, but it can be done to improve its appearance and encourage new growth. Remove dead or yellowing leaves regularly to keep the plant looking tidy. If the plant becomes too dense, thin out some of the inner foliage to allow light and air to reach the center. After flowering, you can cut back the flower stalks to maintain neatness and prevent any unwanted self-seeding. Pruning can be done at any time of the year as needed."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"American plantain","description":"Plantago rugelii is a species of flowering plant in the plantain family, Plantaginaceae. It is native to North America, where it occurs in eastern Canada and the central and eastern United States. Its common names include American plantain, blackseed plantain, pale plantain, and Rugel's plantain. The generic name Plantago is from the Latin planta (\"footprint\") and the species name rugelii honors Ferdinand Ignatius Xavier Rugel (1806-1879), a German-born botanist and pharmacist.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["American plantain"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Plantago rugelii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17830,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Haematoxylum brasiletto, commonly known as the Mexican logwood, thrives with infrequent but deep watering. During the growing season, water the plant every 10 to 14 days, depending on the climate and rainfall. In the winter months, reduce the frequency significantly, only watering when the soil is thoroughly dry. Always ensure good drainage to prevent water from pooling around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Haematoxylum brasiletto requires full sun to thrive, which means it needs at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight each day. It can tolerate and even flourish in very sunny and hot climates, making it ideal for environments where other plants may struggle with intense sunlight. Plant it in a location where it won’t be shadowed by larger trees or structures. While it can survive in partial shade, it may not bloom as prolifically or grow as vigorously as it would in full sun. Adequate sunlight is crucial for the production of vibrant flowers and healthy foliage."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Haematoxylum brasiletto is essential for maintaining a healthy and aesthetically pleasing shape. The best time to prune is during the late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, damaged, or diseased branches to encourage healthy growth. Trimming back stray or overly long branches will help maintain its shape and prevent the plant from becoming leggy. Since this plant naturally grows into a small tree or large shrub, pruning can also be used to train it into a preferred form, such as a multi-trunked shrub or single-trunk tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mexican logwood","description":"Haematoxylum brasiletto, or Mexican logwood, is a species of tropical hardwood tree in the legume family, Fabaceae. It is known in its native Mexico and Guatemala as \"palo de brasil\" or \"palo de tinto\". The timber is used to make bows for stringed instruments, the manufacture of dyes and in ethnobotany.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mexico","Central America"],"other_name":["Mexican logwood"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Haematoxylum brasiletto"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Regularly deadhead the plant by removing spent flowers to prolong blooming periods. Trim back any leggy or overgrown stems to keep the plant compact and tidy. Perform a more substantial prune in early spring, cutting back up to one-third of the plant's volume if necessary, to stimulate fresh growth and rejuvenate the plant. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent disease transmission and ensure healthy cuts."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Yellow-flowered waterhyssop","description":"Mecardonia procumbens, common name baby jump-up, is an annual or perennial herb native to tropical and subtropical regions of the Americas. When cultivating mushrooms like Russula, it's crucial to maintain a consistently humid environment. This can often be achieved by misting the area lightly with water to ensure the substrate remains moist but not waterlogged, mimicking their natural forest floor habitat where they thrive in damp conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Russula cyanoxantha, being a mushroom, does not require direct sunlight like traditional plants for growth. Instead, it thrives in shaded, moist environments typically found on forest floors. When cultivating this mushroom, it’s important to maintain a neutral lighting environment, often simulated using a grow tent or a dark, humid room. Excessive light can dry out the substrate and inhibit growth. Ideal conditions replicate the diffused, low-light conditions they experience in nature, promoting healthy and robust fruiting bodies."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Russula cyanoxantha, as it is a mushroom species. Unlike plants, mushrooms do not require pruning or trimming to promote growth. Instead, focus on maintaining an optimal environment for fruiting. This involves ensuring the substrate remains clean and free of contaminants. If you're cultivating these mushrooms, harvesting them at the right time is key, which is when they have reached full growth but before the cap edges begin to curl upwards. This will ensure the best texture and flavor for consumption."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Charcoal Burner","description":"Russula cyanoxantha, synonymous with R. xyanoxantha, commonly known as the charcoal burner, is a basidiomycete mushroom, distinguished from most other members of the Russula genus by the fact that its gills do not split, but are soft and flexible. Avoid cutting the caudex, the thick base of the plant, as this can lead to infection or stunted growth. Pruning can be limited with this plant as it naturally maintains a compact size, and unnecessary trimming could stress the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"wareque","description":"Ibervillea sonorae is a tuberous perennial plant in the Cucurbitaceae family known by the common names wereke, wareque, guarequi, and coyote melon. If grown indoors or in a greenhouse, consider placing it on a windowsill with a sheer curtain or in a terrarium setting. Artificial lighting can also be used if natural light is insufficient, but ensure it's not too intense to avoid stressing the lichen."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Peltigera canina is not a typical requirement as it does not grow similarly to traditional plants. Carefully trim any sections that appear dry or unhealthy using small scissors or pruning tools. This will prevent the spread of decay and encourage new growth in healthier areas. Handle the lichen gently to avoid damaging it, and ensure your tools are clean to prevent introducing pathogens. Water thoroughly during its growing season (spring through fall), allowing the soil to dry entirely between waterings. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the pot has good drainage. In winter, reduce watering significantly—only water when the plant shows signs of shriveling, typically once a month or less. This mimics its natural habitat, where rain is rare outside of the growing season, helping to prevent the plant from sitting in water for extended periods."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Coryphantha macromeris thrives in full sun, needing at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to maintain its compact growth and vibrant color. If you're growing the cactus indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample light. In very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can protect the plant from scorching. If moved outdoors in the summer, gradually acclimate it to the increased light to prevent sunburn, which can damage the plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not commonly necessary for Coryphantha macromeris, as it naturally maintains its shape and size. However, you can remove any dead or damaged sections using sterilized, sharp cutting tools to encourage healthy growth. This can occasionally stimulate new offsets or pups. Be cautious of the plant’s spines and latex sap, which can irritate the skin. Regular inspection will also help detect any pest infestations or disease that might require intervention."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Nipple Beehive Cactus","description":"Coryphantha macromeris (or the nipple beehive cactus) is a species of cactus in the United States and Mexico. It prefers to grown in the shade under other larger plants, growing in irregular clusters or mounds. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16936,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Rumex confertus, also known as clustered dock, is a hardy perennial that typically does well in moist environments. To care for this plant, ensure that the soil is consistently moist but not waterlogged, as excessive water can lead to root rot. Water the plant generously during dry periods, especially in the summer months, to maintain ideal moisture levels. It's important to reduce watering frequency in colder months to prevent overwatering when the plant's growth slows down. When watering, aim to soak the soil thoroughly and allow the top couple of inches to dry out slightly between sessions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rumex confertus thrives best under full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily to ensure robust growth and flowering. It can tolerate partial shade, but the presence of ample sunlight will promote optimal foliage density and flowering. If grown in too much shade, the plant may become leggy and produce fewer flowers. Positioning it where it receives morning sun and some afternoon shade can protect it from intense sun during the hottest parts of the day, especially in warmer climates."},{"type":"pruning","description":"To effectively manage Rumex confertus, regular pruning can help maintain its shape, promote healthier growth, and prevent it from becoming invasive. Prune in early spring to cut back any dead or diseased stems, using clean pruning shears to make clear and clean cuts near the base. Additionally, removing flower stalks before seeds set will help control the spread of the plant through self-seeding. During the growing season, trimming older leaves and stems can redirect energy to new growth. Be cautious, as this plant can propagate through cuttings left on the ground, so dispose of pruned material carefully."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Russian Dock","description":"Rumex confertus is a flowering plant species in the family Polygonaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Greenish","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Russian Dock"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Rhizome division"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Rumex confertus"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained","Fertile"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16342,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Elephantopus mollis prefers moderately moist soils but is tolerant of occasional dry spells due to its hardy nature. Water this plant when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Over-watering should be avoided as it can lead to root rot; ensure the pot or ground has good drainage to prevent water from pooling. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, you may need to water more frequently, while in fall and winter, reduce watering as the plant enters dormancy. Be attentive to the climate and adjust watering habits accordingly."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Elephantopus mollis thrives in bright, indirect sunlight but can tolerate partial shade. It should be placed where it receives several hours of dappled sunlight each day. Direct, harsh sunlight, especially in the hottest part of the afternoon, may scorch the leaves, so some protection, like a sheer curtain or slight shading, might be needed. If grown indoors, placing it near an east or west-facing window works well. Ensuring proper lighting helps maintain the plant’s vibrant green foliage and promotes healthy flowering during its blooming period."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Elephantopus mollis is generally minimal since it naturally maintains a bushy form. However, you can trim back any dead or damaged leaves and stems periodically to promote healthy growth and improve appearance. Deadheading spent flowers can also encourage more blooming. The ideal time to prune is in early spring, just before the growing season begins. Use clean, sharp garden scissors to make cuts to prevent the spread of disease. Regular pruning will help maintain the plant’s shape and prevent it from becoming too leggy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"elephant's foot","description":"Elephantopus mollis, common names tobacco weed, and soft elephantsfooot, is a tropical species of flowering plant in the sunflower family.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["South America","Central America"],"other_name":["elephant's foot"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Elephantopus mollis"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This can be achieved by regularly misting the area around the fungus or ensuring the substrate doesn't dry out completely. However, avoid excessive watering that might lead to waterlogging or overly soggy conditions, as this can prevent proper air exchange and may lead to mold growth or other forms of rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hydnochaete olivacea thrives in shaded, forest-like environments, as it naturally grows on decaying wood under tree canopies. This fungus does not require direct sunlight and is best maintained in a setting that mimics the dappled light of a forest floor. Indirect sunlight or low light conditions are ideal, and exposure to direct sunlight should be avoided, as it may dry out the fungus and substrate, leading to poor growth conditions. Provide an environment with consistent low light for optimal growth, ensuring humidity levels are adequately maintained."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Since Hydnochaete olivacea is a type of fungus and not a traditional plant, pruning in the conventional sense is not applicable. Instead, focus on maintaining a clean substrate environment where the fungus grows, removing any decaying matter that is overly moldy or not part of the desired fungal growth. Regularly inspect the wood or substrate for competing molds or fungi and gently remove them by hand or with a small brush if necessary. This care helps ensure the fungal body remains healthy and can grow without obstructions."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"brown-toothed crust fungus","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":[],"other_name":["brown-toothed crust fungus"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Hydnochaete olivacea"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Overgrown or leggy plants can be cut back by up to one-third of their height to rejuvenate them. In cultivation or controlled environments, ensure to mist the lichen occasionally using distilled or rainwater, especially in dry climates or periods without natural rainfall. Over-watering should be avoided, as lichens do not tolerate prolonged saturation. Maintain a humid environment without direct water contact if possible, replicating its natural habitat conditions, which are often moist but not overly wet."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cladonia floerkeana, like many lichens, thrives best in dappled sunlight to partial shade. It is adapted to environments where it receives filtered light through tree canopies or indirect sunlight. Direct, harsh sunlight can be damaging, leading to desiccation or discoloration. If grown in controlled environments, provide light that mimics these conditions—bright but not direct, with periodic shade. Maintaining a balance between light exposure and humidity is essential to support the health and growth of this lichen species in non-native settings."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not generally required for Cladonia floerkeana, as lichens do not have the same growth structure as flowering plants or shrubs. However, if the lichen becomes overgrown or collects debris, you may gently clean and manage its shape by carefully removing any external foreign materials or dead sections without damaging the lichen itself. Use soft brushes or simply lightly blow on sensitive areas if necessary. Regular observation and maintenance help ensure that the lichen remains healthy and free from contaminations such as mold or invasive growths."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Gritty British soldiers lichen","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["Gritty British soldiers lichen"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cladonia floerkeana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Acidic","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18020,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Acacia myrtifolia, also known as Myrtle Wattle, is quite drought-tolerant once established. While young, it should be watered regularly to help develop a strong root system. Typically, watering once a week is sufficient during the growing season, reducing the frequency significantly during the winter months. Make sure the soil dries out between watering sessions to prevent root rot. Established plants may only need supplemental watering during extended dry spells. Always water deeply to encourage deep root growth, ensuring the plant thrives under less frequent watering conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acacia myrtifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade. It prefers a location where it receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate some shade, less sunlight may result in reduced flowering and a more open growth habit. If grown in overly shaded areas, the plant may become leggy as it stretches for sunlight. Ideal planting sites include southern or western exposures, which generally provide a suitable mix of light conditions for optimal growth and flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Acacia myrtifolia is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. The best time to prune is after it finishes flowering, typically in late spring or early summer. Remove any dead or diseased wood, and lightly trim branches to maintain the desired shape. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stress the plant. Focus on trimming back any overly long shoots to promote bushier growth. By pruning regularly, you can keep the shrub compact and encourage a more prolific bloom in the following season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Myrtle Wattle","description":"Acacia myrtifolia, known colloquially as myrtle wattle or red-stemmed wattle, is a species of Acacia native to Australia. Its specific epithet 'myrtle-leaved' is derived from the Latin myrtus 'myrtle', and folium 'leaf'. It is a small shrub 0.3–3 m (0.98–9.84 ft) in height, and 2–3 m (6.6–9.8 ft) spread. It has distinctive red branches and lanceolate green phyllodes, 2–9 cm (1-3½ in) in length and 0.5–3 cm wide. Its flowers are creamy white or pale yellow and appear in winter and spring....","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Myrtle Wattle"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Acacia myrtifolia"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Acidic"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17138,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vernicia fordii, commonly known as the Tung Oil Tree, prefers well-drained soil that is kept consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the warmer months, it is vital to water the tree regularly to maintain soil moisture, particularly if there is insufficient rainfall. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. In the cooler months, reduce the frequency of watering, allowing the tree to rest. Ensure proper drainage to prevent root rot, which can occur if the plant sits in standing water. Monitoring soil moisture and adjusting watering practices according to climate conditions is essential."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vernicia fordii thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day to grow optimally. While it can tolerate partial shade, full sun exposure ensures the tree produces its abundant flowers and subsequently, the seeds necessary for tung oil production. If planted in an area with less sunlight, the tree may exhibit slower growth and reduced blooming. Ensure the location chosen for planting has adequate sunlight access throughout the day, avoiding overly shaded or densely planted areas that might obstruct sunlight from reaching the tree effectively."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vernicia fordii should be performed during the dormant season, typically in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Focus on removing any dead, damaged, or diseased branches first to maintain the tree's health. Additionally, thin out overcrowded branches to promote better air circulation and sunlight penetration, which can help prevent fungal diseases. Structurally, prune to maintain a strong central leader and well-spaced primary branches. Avoid heavy pruning as this could induce stress; instead, perform light, strategic cuts to guide its shape and support its health effectively."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"tung oil tree","description":"Vernicia fordii, usually known as the tung tree (Chinese: 桐, tóng) is a species of Vernicia in the spurge family native to southern China, Burma, and northern Vietnam. It is a small to medium-sized deciduous tree growing to 20 m tall, with a spreading crown. The bark is smooth and thin, and bleeds latex if cut. The leaves are alternate, simple, 4.5–25 cm long and 3.5–22 cm broad, heart-shaped or with three shallow, maple-like lobes, green above and...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["China","Myanmar","Vietnam"],"other_name":["tung oil tree"],"pest_susceptibility":["Scale insects"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Vernicia fordii"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If grown indoors or in a garden with variable sun exposure, try to position it in the sunniest spot available to mimic its natural, sun-rich habitat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Caesalpinia cacalaco is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16642,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Melampodium perfoliatum, commonly known as blackfoot daisies, prefer to be kept slightly moist but not overly saturated. Water the plant deeply enough to moisten the root zone and then allow the soil to dry out before the next watering. Typically, watering once a week during the growing season is sufficient, but frequency should be adjusted based on local climate conditions. Ensure the pot or ground has good drainage to prevent root rot. During winter, when the plant's growth slows, reduce watering frequency. Always check the top inch of soil before watering to ensure it has dried out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Melampodium perfoliatum thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sun per day. It is well-suited to bright, sunny locations, which promote robust flowering and growth. In regions with extremely hot climates, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. However, insufficient sunlight can lead to leggy growth and fewer blooms, so prioritize bright positions for planting. If growing indoors, place the plant near the brightest window. Always monitor the plant's response and adjust its position to balance between enough sunlight and not getting too much intense heat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"To ensure healthy growth and a tidy appearance, prune Melampodium perfoliatum regularly. Trim back any dead or damaged flowers and stems throughout the growing season to encourage new blooms. Use a spray bottle to mist the substrate regularly to maintain high humidity, especially if grown indoors. This ensures the mycelium does not dry out and can produce healthy fruiting bodies. It is crucial to avoid overwatering, which can lead to mold and bacterial growth, affecting the mushroom's development. The key is to keep the environment humid, not wet, to mimic the natural conditions where these mushrooms typically grow."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Psilocybe zapotecorum requires indirect sunlight or low light environments, similar to the shaded forests they naturally inhabit. Direct sunlight can dry out the substrate and harm the growth process. However, some light is essential to trigger the fruiting process. If grown indoors, providing light for approximately 12 hours per day is sufficient, mimicking the natural light cycles these mushrooms experience in the wild. Using a fluorescent light or diffused natural light can work well. It's critical to balance providing enough light to stimulate growth without causing excessive drying of the growing medium."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Psilocybe zapotecorum does not require traditional pruning like typical plants. However, it's important to manage the substrate condition and monitor the growth environment. When fruiting bodies appear, they should be harvested once fully grown but typically before the veil breaks to avoid spore release, which can affect continued fruiting. After harvesting, ensure the substrate is cleaned of any debris to avoid contamination. This method of maintenance helps promote consecutive growth cycles and ensures healthier subsequent flushes of mushrooms. It's more about maintaining a clean and suitable growing environment than pruning."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"drunken mushroom","description":"Psilocybe zapotecorum is a psilocybin mushroom which has psilocybin and psilocin as main active compounds. The soil should never be allowed to dry out completely, but it also should not be waterlogged as this can cause root rot. It's advisable to water lightly but frequently, allowing the top layer of soil to dry slightly between watering sessions. Always use lukewarm water, and if possible, collect rainwater or use distilled water instead of tap water which can be harsh due to chlorine and other chemicals."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Anogramma leptophylla thrives in partial shade to full shade conditions. It prefers dappled sunlight similar to the under-canopy lighting conditions found in its native habitat. Direct sunlight, especially during the hottest parts of the day, can scorch its delicate fronds. When grown indoors, place the fern near a north or east-facing window where it can receive indirect light. If the naturally available light is too intense, consider using sheer curtains to diffuse it. Maintaining the right light balance is crucial for its growth and health throughout the year."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Anogramma leptophylla is generally not necessary since it is an annual fern that completes its life cycle within a year. However, you can enhance its appearance by removing any dead or damaged fronds throughout its growing season. Use sharp, sterilized scissors or pruning shears to cut these fronds back to the base. Regularly removing debris and yellowing leaves will encourage healthy growth and prevent pest infestations. Once the plant starts to die back at the end of its cycle, you can remove all foliage to tidy up the area as it will not regenerate."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Jersey fern","description":"Anogramma leptophylla, sometimes called Jersey fern, is a species of fern in the family Pteridaceae. It is found worldwide in temperate and subtropical regions. A rarity in the Pteridophyta, it is a fern whose sporophyte tends to have an annual life cycle. The gametophytes of this species have the ability to become dormant and wait as much as two and a half years until conditions are appropriate for the sporophyte stage of the life-cycle.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","Africa","Western Asia"],"other_name":["Jersey fern"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spores"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Anogramma leptophylla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If growing indoors or in an area where full sun isn't available, ensure it receives bright, indirect light and consider supplementing with grow lights if necessary. Lack of adequate sunlight can result in leggy growth and reduced flowering. If the plant becomes too dense, selectively thin out crowded branches to allow sunlight penetration. During hot, dry periods, you may need to water more frequently, especially if the plant is in a container. Reduce watering in the dormant winter months to allow the plant to rest. Ensure the plant is positioned where it can receive adequate sunlight to maintain its growth and flowering. If growing indoors or in a shaded garden, consider supplemental grow lights to mimic full sun exposure for healthier development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Prune Glandularia wrightii to encourage a more compact growth and to promote continuous blooming. Deadhead spent flowers regularly to prolong blooming throughout the season. In late winter or early spring, cut back the plant by about one-third to remove any dead or leggy stems and encourage robust growth. This maintenance helps rejuvenate the plant and can prevent it from becoming too woody. Be gentle when pruning, and make clean cuts to avoid damaging the plant. Avoid waterlogging or letting the soil dry out completely. It’s best to check the top inch of soil; if it feels dry, it’s time to water. Using a layer of mulch can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vernonia angustifolia thrives in full sun to partial shade. However, in areas with intense afternoon sun, some light shade can prevent scorching and help the plant maintain its vigor. Ensure adequate sunlight exposure for the best display of its striking purple flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vernonia angustifolia involves cutting back stems to encourage bushier growth and to remove dead or damaged parts. In spring, trim back the old growth to the base to stimulate new shoots. During the growing season, remove spent flowers to promote continued blooming and limit seeding. This not only enhances the plant’s overall appearance but also encourages vigorous growth and flowering. In late fall or early winter, you can cut the plant down to ground level after it has died back, which prepares it for the next growth cycle."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Narrow Leaf Ironweed","description":"Vernonia angustifolia is a species of flowering plant in the family Asteraceae, native to the southeastern United States (Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina and South Carolina). Mulching around the base helps retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Astroloma humifusum prefers full sun to partial shade to thrive. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16153,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carex pallescens, also known as pale sedge, prefers moist soil conditions. It should be watered regularly to maintain the moisture level of the soil, but be careful to avoid waterlogging as this can lead to root rot. Generally, watering once a week should suffice in maintaining adequate moisture, but in extremely dry periods, it may need to be watered more frequently. It is important to allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Adjust the watering schedule based on rainfall and humidity levels to ensure that the plant is not sitting in overly wet soil."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex pallescens thrives best in partial to full shade, making it an excellent option for shaded gardens or areas with indirect sunlight. While it can tolerate some morning sun, it generally prefers cooler environments with protection from the harsh midday and afternoon sun. Too much sun exposure can lead to leaf burn and stunted growth. In full shade, it will maintain its lush green color and continue to grow healthily. If planted in an area with more exposure, monitor for signs of stress and consider providing additional shade if needed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Carex pallescens is relatively straightforward. It should be trimmed back in early spring before new growth begins. This involves cutting away dead or damaged leaves to promote healthy growth and a neater appearance. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17040,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Swietenia macrophylla, commonly known as bigleaf mahogany, requires moderate watering. Young trees should be watered regularly to establish a strong root system, particularly during dry periods. It is important to ensure the soil is well-drained to prevent waterlogging, which can be detrimental to the plant's health. As the tree matures, it becomes more drought-tolerant and may only need occasional deep watering during extended dry spells. The key is to keep the soil consistently moist without allowing it to become soggy."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Swietenia macrophylla thrives in full sunlight, which promotes healthy growth and wood development. It is best suited to locations where it can receive at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight daily. Partial shade is tolerated, especially for young saplings, but full sun exposure supports optimal photosynthesis and growth rates. When planting Swietenia macrophylla, choose a spot with unobstructed access to sunlight, bearing in mind its potential to grow into a large tree, which could overshadow smaller plants."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Swietenia macrophylla should be done primarily to maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. The best time to prune is during the dry season or at the end of the growth cycle to prevent sap loss. Light pruning can also encourage a bushier, more compact growth. Care should be taken to sterilize pruning tools to prevent the spread of disease. Over-pruning should be avoided, as it can stress the tree and slow growth, reducing the ornamental and timber quality of the tree."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Big-leaf Mahogany","description":"Swietenia macrophylla, commonly known as mahogany, Honduran mahogany, Honduras mahogany, big-leaf mahogany, or West Indian mahogany, is a species of plant in the Meliaceae family. It is one of three species that yields genuine mahogany timber, the others being Swietenia mahagoni and Swietenia humilis. It is native to South America and Mexico, but naturalized in Singapore and Hawaii, and cultivated in plantations and wind-breaks elsewhere.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","South America"],"other_name":["Big-leaf Mahogany"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf miner","Mahogany shoot borer"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Swietenia macrophylla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Cut back long, leggy stems to encourage bushier growth. It's also beneficial to trim back one-third of the previous year's growth to stimulate new shoots. Sterilize pruning tools before and after use to prevent the spread of disease. It is drought-tolerant once established, so over-watering should be avoided. Allow the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings to prevent root rot. Overall, ensure that the plant receives ample sunlight to maintain its vibrant growth and prolific blooming."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cosmos parviflorus involves removing dead or fading flowers to encourage more blooms and maintain a tidy appearance. Deadheading is most effective if done regularly throughout the blooming season. You can also trim back the plant by a third if it becomes too tall or scraggly. This not only helps in promoting bushier growth but also prolongs the flowering period. At the end of the growing season, you may cut back the plant if you desire a neater garden or leave it until spring if you want to provide habitat for beneficial insects."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"southwestern cosmos","description":"Cosmos parviflorus is a North American species of plants in the sunflower family. Common names include southwestern cosmos in the US and juve or aceitilla blanca in Mexico. Filtered light, such as that provided by deciduous trees, is ideal. In areas with higher temperatures, increased shade will be beneficial during the summer months. Ensuring enough shelter from direct sunlight will promote lush foliage growth and vibrant blooms in spring. In gardening zones suitable for woodlands, partial shade is optimal."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Hepatica acutiloba is minimal as this plant naturally maintains a good shape. It's not recommended to cut back living foliage during the growing season, as leaves are essential for photosynthesis and energy storage. Avoid trimming flower stems once they have spent, as they can naturally drop seeds for propagation. Ensure that the soil is kept consistently moist, especially during its active growing season in late spring and summer. However, it is important to avoid waterlogging because overly wet conditions can lead to root rot. During dry spells, additional watering might be needed to maintain moist soil. In contrast, reduce watering during the plant's dormancy period in the winter months, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. A layer of organic mulch can help retain soil moisture and reduce the frequency of watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Rudbeckia texana thrives in full sun conditions, requiring at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight daily to promote vigorous growth and abundant flowering. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, insufficient sunlight may lead to reduced flowering and leggy growth. Planting in a location with ample sunlight ensures the plant develops strong stems and vibrant blooms. If grown in shady areas, the plant might become susceptible to ailments and can struggle to bloom as profusely. Morning sun exposure is particularly beneficial to avoid scorching during extremely hot afternoon temperatures."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Rudbeckia texana involves removing spent blooms regularly, known as deadheading, to encourage more flowers and extend the blooming period. After the flowering season, the stems can be cut back to ground level to tidy up the plant and prevent seed production if self-seeding is not desired. In early spring, pruning any dead or damaged growth will promote healthy new growth. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of disease. Pruning also helps maintain the plant's shape and size, especially in garden settings."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Texas Coneflower","description":"Rudbeckia texana, commonly known at Texas coneflower or shiny coneflower, is a perennial plant in the sunflower family native to the Western Gulf coastal grasslands of Texas and Louisiana.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Texas Coneflower"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Rudbeckia texana"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Direct sunlight can scorch the fronds, so it's best to provide filtered or dappled sunlight throughout the day. If placing indoors, select a spot near an east or north-facing window that receives indirect light. Ensure it does not receive intense direct afternoon sun. If grown outside, a location with partial shade is ideal, allowing the plant to enjoy some sun without being exposed to harsh rays."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cyathea dregei involves removing dead or damaged fronds to maintain its appearance and health. This can be done any time of the year. Use clean, sharp pruning scissors to cut the fronds close to the trunk, being careful not to damage the new croziers (young fronds). Removal of old fronds also helps in preventing disease and pest infestation. Regularly check the plant and remove old foliage to encourage new growth and to keep the plant looking tidy and vigorous."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Grassveld Tree Fern","description":"Cyathea dregei, also known as the Common Tree Fern and Gewone Boomvaring in Afrikaans, is a widespread species of tree fern in southern Africa. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":18012,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Hottonia palustris, also known as water violet, prefers consistently moist to wet conditions. Since it is an aquatic plant, it thrives when completely submerged in water such as ponds or slow-moving streams. If growing in a container or garden, ensure that the soil remains saturated and does not dry out. Water temperatures should be kept moderate, and in colder climates, some protection may be necessary during the winter months to prevent freezing. Always keep the water table steady and avoid drastic changes in water conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hottonia palustris thrives in full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, it should receive at least four to six hours of sunlight each day for optimal growth and flowering; however, it can tolerate shaded conditions, which might result in less vigorous blooming. Full sun encourages more robust growth and flowering, but in regions with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help reduce stress. Situate the plant in a location where it can enjoy an abundance of ambient light without being overshadowed by larger vegetation."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Hottonia palustris primarily involves removing dead or damaged foliage to maintain plant health and appearance. It is best to prune in early spring before new growth starts or in late autumn after flowering. Remove any brown or decaying leaves at the base to prevent rot and to improve water circulation. Occasionally thinning out the plant may also be necessary to prevent overcrowding and to allow light to reach the submerged parts. Proper pruning will encourage a denser growth and more vibrant blooms."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Water Violet","description":"Hottonia palustris, also water violet or featherfoil, is an aquatic plant in the family Primulaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Water Violet"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Hottonia palustris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16434,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Geranium sibiricum prefers moderate watering. It is important to keep the soil consistently moist but not waterlogged. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, ensure that the plant receives sufficient water to promote healthy growth. However, be cautious to avoid overwatering, as excess moisture can lead to root rot. In the winter, reduce the frequency of watering as the plant's growth slows significantly, allowing the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings. Observing the plant's response and local climate conditions will help adjust the watering schedule appropriately."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Geranium sibiricum thrives in full sunlight to partial shade, requiring at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth and flowering. If grown in a very hot climate, providing some afternoon shade can prevent foliage scorch and help maintain vibrant blooms. In cooler climates, full sun exposure ensures the plant receives enough light to develop robustly. Placing the plant in a location with morning sun and afternoon shade often yields the best results, allowing it to enjoy warmth and light while being protected from harsh midday rays."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Geranium sibiricum involves removing dead or damaged leaves and stems to promote healthy growth and maintain the plant's shape. After the flowering period, deadheading spent blooms encourages continuous blooming and prevents seed formation, focusing the plant's energy on growth. In early spring, prune any winter-damaged stems to make way for new growth. Ensure that cuts are clean and made just above a leaf node to encourage branching. Regular pruning helps keep the plant tidy and prevents it from becoming too leggy, ensuring a bushy and attractive appearance throughout the growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Siberian Crane's-bill","description":null,"family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Siberia","Eastern Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["Siberian Crane's-bill"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Geranium sibiricum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sand"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16237,"attracts":["Butterflies","Hummingbirds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cordia sebestena, commonly known as the Geiger Tree, prefers well-draining soil and should be watered regularly, but only when the top inch of soil feels dry. It's important not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. During the growing season, typically spring and summer, more frequent watering is necessary, while in the cooler months, the plant requires less water. Ensure adequate drainage and avoid letting the plant sit in water to maintain healthy growth."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Cordia sebestena thrives in full sun conditions but can tolerate partial shade. For optimal growth and flowering, it should receive at least six to eight hours of direct sunlight per day. Inadequate sunlight can lead to sparse flowering and leggy growth. If cultivating indoors or in a garden area with limited sun exposure, supplementary grow lights can help provide the necessary light intensity for healthy development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cordia sebestena is essential for maintaining its shape and encouraging healthy growth. Pruning should be done in late winter or early spring before the onset of new growth. Remove dead or diseased branches first, and then cut back any overly long or unruly branches to maintain a balanced shape. Regular pruning helps to enhance flowering by allowing light to penetrate the inner branches and promotes a fuller canopy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Scarlet Cordia","description":"Cordia sebestena is a shrubby tree in the borage family, Boraginaceae, native to the American tropics. It ranges from southern Florida in the United States and the Bahamas, southwards throughout Central America and the Greater Antilles. Common names have included siricote or kopté (Mayan) in 19th Century northern Yucatán, scarlet cordia in Jamaica, and Geiger tree (after Key West wrecker John Geiger) in Florida.","family":null,"flower_color":"Orange","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"White\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Central America","Caribbean","South Florida"],"other_name":["Scarlet Cordia"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew","Leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Cordia sebestena"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16147,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Carex hirtifolia, also known as the hairy sedge, prefers consistently moist soil. It is important to water this plant regularly, especially during dry periods, to maintain soil moisture. However, ensure that the plant is not waterlogged, as this can lead to root rot or other fungal issues. During its active growing season in spring and summer, increase watering frequency to ensure optimal growth. In fall and winter, reduce the frequency of watering as the plant enters dormancy. Mulching can help retain soil moisture and provide a more consistent environment for the plant's roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Carex hirtifolia thrives best in partial to full shade conditions, making it an ideal plant for woodland gardens or shaded borders. While it can tolerate some morning sun, exposure to full sun can lead to stress and require more frequent watering to prevent the soil from drying out. The plant’s preference for dappled or indirect sunlight ensures it remains healthy and retains its lush green appearance. Providing some protection from the harsh afternoon sun will help avoid leaf scorch and maintain a steady growth rate throughout its growing season."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Carex hirtifolia minimally is often enough to keep the plant healthy and attractive. It is generally advisable to trim back dead or damaged foliage in early spring before new growth begins. This helps to maintain the plant's aesthetic appearance and encourages fresh, healthy growth. Avoid excessive pruning as this can stress the plant. Additionally, removing seed heads in the autumn, if not needed for propagation or wildlife, can prevent self-seeding and keep the plant tidy. Regularly check the base and center of the plant for dead or decaying material and remove as necessary."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"hairy sedge","description":"Carex hirtifolia, the pubescent sedge, is a species of sedge native to north-eastern North America. It is the only species in Carex section Hirtifoliae. The entire plant is distinctively covered soft hairs.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["hairy sedge"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Dividing"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Carex hirtifolia"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":16336,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Echinocereus viridiflorus, commonly known as the Green Pitaya, requires careful watering routines for optimal growth. During its active growing season, from spring to summer, water the plant thoroughly when the soil has fully dried out. This mimics its natural, erratic rain patterns in its native habitat. Reduce watering frequency significantly in fall and winter, allowing the soil to remain nearly dry, as the cactus is dormant and requires minimal moisture. Overwatering should be avoided at all costs as it can lead to root rot. Use a well-draining cactus mix to prevent water retention."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Echinocereus viridiflorus thrives in bright sunlight and is best suited for locations that provide full sun exposure for at least six hours a day. In its natural habitat, this cactus enjoys intense, direct sunlight, and replicating this environment will encourage optimal growth and flowering. If grown indoors, place it near a south-facing window where it will receive ample light. However, during the hottest part of the summer, some afternoon shade can prevent sunburn, especially in regions with very intense sunlight. Gradually acclimate it to increase sunlight exposure after any moving or repotting."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Echinocereus viridiflorus is generally minimal due to its slow-growing nature. However, it's beneficial to remove any dead or damaged parts of the plant occasionally to promote healthier growth. This can be done using clean, sharp tools to cut away unwanted sections, being careful not to damage the healthy parts. Additionally, removing pups (small offshoots) can help control the plant's size and encourage more robust growth in the main plant. Ensure that all removed parts are healthy and free from disease before attempting to root them elsewhere."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Green-flower Hedgehog Cactus","description":"Echinocereus viridiflorus is a species of cactus known by the common names nylon hedgehog cactus, green pitaya, and small-flowered hedgehog cactus. It is native to the central and south-central United States and northern Mexico, where it can be found in varied habitat types, including desert scrub, woodlands, dry grasslands, and short-grass prairie.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Green\"]","growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States","Mexico"],"other_name":["Green-flower Hedgehog Cactus"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Echinocereus viridiflorus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":17229,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Arenga engleri, commonly known as the Dwarf Sugar Palm, prefers moderate watering. It is crucial to maintain a balance by ensuring the soil stays slightly moist but not waterlogged, as overwatering can lead to root rot. Take care to water more frequently during the warmer months or if the plant is located indoors where the air may be drier. In cooler months, allow the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings. Well-draining soil is essential to help prevent excess water retention around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Arenga engleri thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. It can tolerate partial shade, which makes it suitable for growing under taller trees or on shaded patios. Direct sunlight, especially during the hottest part of the day, can scorch the leaves. If kept indoors, place the plant near a window where it can receive filtered sunlight. It’s important to rotate the plant periodically to ensure even growth on all sides. Providing the right amount of light will promote healthy growth and prevent leaf discoloration."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Arenga engleri involves removing dead or damaged fronds to keep the plant healthy and enhance its appearance. It is best to prune in the spring when the plant begins active growth. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to cut the fronds at the base near the trunk. This plant can absorb moisture through its leaves, so misting them occasionally can be beneficial, especially in dry environments. Be careful not to let water sit in the central \"cup\" of the plant for too long, as stagnant water can lead to rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aechmea bracteata thrives in bright, indirect sunlight. When grown indoors, place the plant near a window with filtered light, such as through sheer curtains. If grown outdoors, choose a spot with dappled shade or under the canopy of larger plants. If the leaves start to fade or bleach, it may be getting too much light, whereas if growth slows and the plant becomes leggy, it may need more light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Aechmea bracteata is minimal and mainly involves removing dead or damaged leaves to keep the plant looking tidy and healthy. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to cut off any brown or withered foliage close to the base. After the plant flowers, the bloom will eventually fade, and it can be cut off to allow the plant to direct energy into new growth. Additionally, as the plant produces offsets or pups, these can be separated and potted individually once they are a decent size, further aiding the overall health of the mother plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"vase bromeliad","description":"Aechmea bracteata is a species in the genus Aechmea. In less sunny areas, monitor plant health and adjust its location as needed."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ruellia drummondiana can help maintain its shape and promote bushier growth. It's best to prune in early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems to encourage healthy growth. You can also trim back leggy stems to achieve a more compact appearance. It's important to avoid excessive water accumulation which may water-log the fungal media used for growth, ensuring a balance where the substrate is moist but not water-saturated."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hypomyces hyalinus naturally grows on fungi and thrives in environments akin to those of its hosts, which are often shaded forest floors with minimal direct sunlight. Direct sunlight can be detrimental due to its potential to desiccate or overheat the delicate fungal structures. If grown indoors, placing it under artificial grow lights can help manage light exposure effectively, ensuring it receives an appropriate level of light without the risk of drying out."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable for Hypomyces hyalinus as it is a fungus rather than a plant. Typically, fungi do not require pruning. However, if you are cultivating it, ensure its growth medium, such as the surface of its host fungus, remains clean and free from competing fungi. Regularly check for discoloration or mold, which might indicate contamination. Remove any dead or decaying fungal tissue carefully to prevent the spread of unwanted organisms, taking care not to damage the Hypomyces hyalinus itself."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Amanita Mold","description":"Hypomyces hyalinus is a species of parasitic fungi that attacks fungi of the genus Amanita. Always ensure the plant receives adequate sunlight to maintain its overall health and productivity."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Manilkara zapota should be done primarily to maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased wood. This can be done during the late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Trim any crossing or inward-facing branches to allow better air circulation and sunlight penetration. Avoid heavy pruning as it might affect fruit production; instead, aim for gradual shaping over time."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Sapodilla","description":"Manilkara zapota, commonly known as the sapodilla (/ˌsæpəˈdɪlə/), is a long-lived, evergreen tree native to southern Mexico, Central America and the Caribbean. It is essential to allow the soil to dry out between waterings, avoiding any excess moisture that could lead to root rot. During the growing season, water the plant thoroughly but ensure proper drainage. In winter, reduce watering frequency, as the plant requires less moisture during its dormant period. Always check the soil moisture level before watering; the top couple of inches should be dry before you water again, ensuring the plant remains healthy and vibrant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pittosporum viridiflorum thrives best in full sun to partial shade. Ideally, the plant should receive at least 4 to 6 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal growth. While it can tolerate partial shade, too much shade may result in leggy growth and fewer flowers. In hotter climates, providing afternoon shade will protect the plant from intense sun, which can cause leaf scorch. In tropical or subtropical regions, where the plant is more accustomed, it can handle more sun exposure. Adjust its sunlight exposure based on your specific climate conditions for the best results."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pittosporum viridiflorum is generally needed to control its size and shape, as well as to remove any dead or diseased branches. The best time to prune is in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Use clean, sharp pruning shears to make cuts at an angle, removing branches that cross or a crowd the center of the plant. Prune lightly to maintain a natural shape, and avoid heavy pruning that could stress the plant. Regular maintenance pruning will encourage denser growth and keep the plant healthy and attractive."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Cape Cheesewood","description":"Pittosporum viridiflorum (Cape cheesewood, Afrikaans: Kasuur, Sotho: Kgalagangwe, Xhosa: Umkhwenkwe, Zulu: Umfusamvu) is a protected tree in South Africa.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Black\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Southern Africa","Eastern Africa"],"other_name":["Cape Cheesewood"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Pittosporum viridiflorum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

This perennial enjoys sunny, open areas, which help to produce its best blooms and maintain healthy, vibrant foliage. To ensure the plant grows robustly and flowers optimally, place it in a location where it receives ample sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Pityopsis falcata is generally not a demanding task. Deadheading spent blooms can help promote continued blooming and maintain a tidy appearance. In late fall or early spring, trim back any dead or damaged foliage to encourage fresh growth. While regular pruning is not necessary for this plant, occasional trimming helps manage its shape and encourages a more vigorous regrowth in the next growing season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Sickleleaf Silk-grass","description":"Pityopsis falcata, common names sickleleaf silkgrass and sickle-leaved golden aster, is perennial species of flowering plant in the aster family that is native to the United States and has been introduced to Canada.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Sickleleaf Silk-grass"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["May"],"scientific_name":["Pityopsis falcata"],"soil":["Sandy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During prolonged periods of drought or intense summer heat, occasional deep watering is beneficial. Ensure the plant is in well-draining soil to prevent waterlogged conditions which can cause root rot. For potted plants, water thoroughly and let the excess drain away, but reduce watering frequency during cooler months."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Echium italicum thrives in full sun conditions, needing at least 6 to 8 hours of sunlight per day. It grows best in environments where it receives direct sunlight, as this encourages robust flowering and healthy foliage. Although tolerant of partial shade, too much shade might lead to leggy growth and reduced flowering. If grown in a pot indoors, place it near a bright, south-facing window to maximize light exposure. Ensure the sun exposure is consistent, especially during the growing seasons of spring and summer, for optimal plant health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Echium italicum is minimal but may be beneficial to maintain its shape and encourage bushier growth. It is best to prune after flowering, removing any dead flower spikes and any part of the plant that appears straggly or dead. This not only tidies the plant but also prevents self-seeding if you don't want it to spread too much. Be cautious while pruning, as the leaves and stems may be somewhat prickly. Always use clean, sharp pruning shears to make clean cuts and reduce the risk of transmitting plant diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Pale Bugloss","description":"Echium italicum, the Italian viper's bugloss, Lady Campbell weed, or pale bugloss, is a species of plant from Boraginaceae family, that can be found in the Mediterranean Basin (especially in Italy, hence the name 'italicum') and, as an introduced species in the United States (for example in the state of Maryland).","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean","Central Europe"],"other_name":["Pale Bugloss"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Echium italicum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Humidity levels between 85-95% in a controlled environment can help create favorable growing conditions for these fungi."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Hypholoma sublateritium naturally grows in shaded or partially shaded environments, such as on decaying wood in forests. Excessive light can lead to drying of the fruiting bodies, so ensure any artificial lighting is diffuse and not too intense, maintaining a balance to support healthy growth."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to mushrooms like Hypholoma sublateritium. As a fungus, it's important to focus on environmental conditions rather than pruning. If growing in a controlled setting, regularly check for signs of contamination in the growth media and remove any affected areas to prevent spread. Ensure that harvested mushrooms are picked carefully to prevent damage to the mycelium, which could affect future growth. Regularly removing old or decayed fruiting bodies can help maintain cleanliness in the growing area."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Brick Cap","description":"Hypholoma lateritium, sometimes called brick cap, is rarer and less well-known than its relatives, the inedible, and poisonous sulfur tuft (Hypholoma fasciculare) and the edible Hypholoma capnoides. If planted in a shaded area, expect a slower growth rate and possible leggy appearance of branches as the plant reaches for sunlight. It is also beneficial to thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation within the plant, which reduces the risk of fungal diseases. Avoid heavy pruning as the plant should be allowed to maintain its natural form as much as possible. This will encourage new growth and improve the plant's natural shape. While the plant can tolerate some light shaping, avoid heavy pruning, as this can lead to stress. If you’re looking to control the plant's size or shape, prune conservatively. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and prevent infection or damage to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Adam's tree","description":"Fouquieria diguetii, known by the common names Adam's tree and palo Adán, is a plant in the family Fouquieriaceae native to the southern half of the Baja California Peninsula, and the coasts of Sonora and Sinaloa. It should be watered sparingly once established, as it is adapted to survive in arid environments. During the first growing season, provide regular, moderate water to help establish a deep root system. After the plant is established, it requires minimal watering, only during prolonged dry spells. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure the soil has excellent drainage and allow the topsoil to dry out completely between waterings."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ipomoea leptophylla thrives in full sun and requires a location that receives at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. It is well-suited to open, sunny spaces where it can receive abundant light, which is crucial for its growth and flowering. While it can handle partial shade, optimal blooming and plant health are achieved with full sun exposure. In regions with intense summer heat, some afternoon shade can help prevent leaf scorch, but generally, more sun equates to more blooms for this sun-loving plant."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ipomoea leptophylla is minimal. The plant naturally forms a bushy shape but can be pruned to maintain size or encourage bushier growth. Remove dead or damaged stems in the fall after flowering has finished. While it is not necessary for flower production or plant health, light pruning in early spring can help maintain an attractive shape and remove any undesirable growth. Cutting back too much can stunt growth, so limit pruning to shaping and cleaning up the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bush Morning-glory","description":"Ipomoea leptophylla, the bush morning glory, bush moonflower or manroot, is a flowering plant species in the bindweed family, Convolvulaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Bush Morning-glory"],"pest_susceptibility":["Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Ipomoea leptophylla"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In particularly hot climates, the plant may benefit from some afternoon shade to prevent sunburn on its leaves. If grown indoors, position it near a south or west-facing window to ensure it gets sufficient light. Insufficient sunlight can cause the plant to become leggy as it stretches towards the light source, so consider supplemental grow lights if natural sunlight is inadequate."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Sedum ebracteatum is relatively straightforward and typically only necessary to maintain its shape or remove dead or damaged leaves. Use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to make precise cuts. In early spring, prune away any leggy growth to encourage a bushier appearance. Also, remove any spent flower stalks after blooming to maintain a tidy look. If the plant becomes too large, you can trim it back, and the cuttings can often be propagated to create new plants.
